note.body:
I searched the source code and found glycin's loader configuration file is using image/x-qoi instead of the authors mimetype, image/qoi. I added this in /usr/share/glycin-loaders/1+/conf.d/glycin-image-rs.conf but this did not fix it. This is the line I added
```
[loader:image/qoi]
Exec=/usr/libexec/glycin-loaders/1+/glycin-image-rs
```

target_title: Cache images for session already loaded once

note.body:
Ok let me check. Ah i guess this is not only related to the HDD that is attached to my computer, when copying the files to the internal nvme drive (which is encrypted, so is the HDD) then still shows the same image loading indicator moving back and forth between the images after about \~3 images. Running a quick speed check on the nvme1 it shows:

> sudo hdparm -tT /dev/nvme1n1
>
> /dev/nvme1n1:
>
> Timing cached reads: 23928 MB in 2.00 seconds = 11984.84 MB/sec
>
> Timing buffered disk reads: 7602 MB in 3.00 seconds = 2533.37 MB/sec

So at least in theory it should read all images in less than 1sec, but processing is taking more time + \~ 2sec.

target_title: Choppy/stuck pinch-to-zoom with certain webp images

note.body:
Flatpak image viewer 47.2.

![AMZ-GALLERY-CODA56-01](/uploads/2e52df1f534c7a1c1716c293e92d4a8f/AMZ-GALLERY-CODA56-01.webp)

For the following image the zoom out (-) button is greyed out after opening image. Zoom in (+) is active and clicking the button zooms in the image.

Steps to repeat:

1. open image
2. click zoom in button once
3. use pinch to zoom in and out and observe it works with trackpad
4. use pinch to zoom out all the way until you see the zoom in (-) button greyed out again
5. observe pinch to zoom in with the trackpad now no longer works (two finger swipe left to right for next image still works)

Print preview for SVGs not working

note.body:
Findings so far

- `image.specific_frame(frame_request).await` is no longer polled after being polled two times, returning `Pending`.
- It works with all other executors but `glib`.
- Looks like `futures_executor::ThreadPool::new().unwrap().spawn_ok()` would be a workaround for 47 without adding crates.

target_title: CLI option: `--slideshow`

note.body:
Yes, I want to open the pictures in full screen mode, would be nice if one could define the transition time from one image to another from CLI as well. This is  useful to visualize pictures in a folder. 
e.g. `loupe --slideshow --time=3 "${PWD}"` (or -s, and -t; time is in seconds)

Also if instead of Folder at the end of the command if input is a list of pictures, then it should slideshow those images in that order

e.g.

```
find . -name '*Germany.jpg' | sort | loupt -s -t 3 - 
```

here `-` can indicate stdin input

target_title: Touchpad zoom doesn't work after activating fullscreen via double click

note.body:
Thanks for reporting the issue!

I can reproduce it on shell/mutter 47.

- Double-click an image in Files
- Double-click on the image in Loupe
- Try to zoom or rotate the image via touchpad gesture doesn't work

However

- Two-finger swipe on touchpad to change images works
- For other images, the zoom and rotate gestures work

To me, this looks like the issue is limited to the widget that handled the double-click (GtkGestureClick). Which sounds like it's probably a GTK and not a Mutter issue?

The GtkGestureZoom and GtkGestureRotate never get a "begin" signal. If the fullscreen is activated via F11 or the fullscreen button, the bug is not present.

The issue is only present if the double-click activates the fullscreen mode. If there is a handler but it does not activate fullscreen, the bug is also not present.

target_title: Blurry svg rendering

Can you make sure if you opened the image by directly opening it through the files.

![Screencast_From_2024-11-17_18-39-27](/uploads/dd1455f5e2f4f78ca2e3833f2b45846a/Screencast_From_2024-11-17_18-39-27.mp4)

target_title: Image Editing: Crop

note.body:
What do you think about the first bullet point of my comment?

> Currently, dragging moves the selection rectangle. If you have already pressed 'Apply', it is not possible to get back parts of the image that are outside the selection without resetting everything. My suggestion is to move the image within the selection rectangle instead, and perhaps even allow zooming in and out. This would make it possible to increase the size of the selection without having to reset everything. It would also be similar to panning and zooming when viewing an image.

target_title: Image Editing: Crop

note.body:
Thank you for taking the time to clarify why you feel like that. I appreciate that very much!

I realize that my comment could be read as ignoring your opinion on automatic cropping and I'm sorry about that. That was not my intention at all. I can completely understand that some people might have problems with the auto-apply feature used in some mobile applications. I personally do not have this problem and just wanted to give my subjective feedback that I struggle with the explicit apply behavior and prefer the automatic apply. This was not meant to convince you, as I'm aware of your statement that you "don't want to use it here". I should have been more considerate in the wording of that part of the comment.

target_title: Fix regression of showing image information compared to eog.

note.body: Which part of loupe has still a long way to go before it's even usable, even after a year of being the default, didn't you get? This isn't about preference, this is about making something the default that's just completely broken (see #139 rendering loupe completely useless with images with transparency and yet no usable way for the user to fix this other than installing a different program) and just ignoring glaring issues. This is about making something a default that obviously still has years to go until it's more than a beta at best, judging from major issues having absolutely no solution even a year after they've been opened. Making loupe the default image viewer is clearly a failed experiment that should be reverted if UX matters in any way to Gnome. Just doing whatever and not giving a flying fuck about consequences is how you make people leave/fork your stuff. And given the financial issues of Gnome even while a company as big as Red Hat is the driving force behind it, it might not be the smartest idea to flip your users off. And I wouldn't be surprised if RH reverted your decision on making loupe a default. When you have customers paying you for your support contracts, and you give them a half broken mess, you'll have to look for customers stupid enough to accept such a bad deal as the ones you have will have been your customers for the longest time...

target_title: Fix regression of showing image information compared to eog.

note.body: If you like eog better, just keep using it.

target_title: Touchpad zoom doesn't work after activating fullscreen via double click
Fix regression of showing image information compared to eog.

note.body: If this was just some app I wouldn't bother. But when people decide it is good enough to replace another application as default, it should not be that much worse (this by far isn't the only issue with it). This is not remotely better, so either it should get there asap or it should be dropped as a default until it's actually capable doing so. Leaving users with such an incomplete mess that's perfectly unusable with anything that has transparency is just very bad decision making.

target_title: Fix regression of showing image information compared to eog.

note.body:
I think you should reconsider the way you interact with volunteers whose work you are using for free.

@sophie-h is under no obligation to fix your pet issues.

target_title: Image Editing: Crop

note.body:
@PhilippSauberz for your question why I got the feeling that you are not considering the existing comments, take this section from my comment

> Mobile apps do stuff like automatically applying the crop after a second, but I always struggled with that so I don't want to use it here.

I don't see how your comment is considering it:

> I'm so used to the selection being applied after a short delay on iOS. There it is applied 1 second or so after the last time the selection was adjusted or the image moved or zoomed. Combined with my suggestion above to move and zoom the image within the selection rectangle, I think we could get rid of this button.

Independent of that

> Some image editors allow you to increase the selection indefinitely by zooming out at a constant rate once a certain threshold has been reached by dragging the mouse away from the selection handles. Personally, I have never found this to work well.

Very much agreed that one also always felt uncontrollable to me.

target_title: Loupe becomes unresponsive while opening 30,000x30,000 image

Since Loupe 47 with GTK 4.16 images without transparency and huge resolutions should be much much better supported. They should load faster while also not causing the previous crashes or hangs. The only price is that they might be slightly slower to zoom in.

However, there is still an issue with transparent images that needs to be fixed.

target_title: Fix regression of showing image information compared to eog.

note.body: Please stop closing issues that clearly have not been fixed. This is a regression and should be treated as such. If you don't want to put in the effort to make loupe an acceptable replacement for eog, maybe just don't have it promoted to default. When a default program is being replaced, that replacement should be at least as good as the program or replaces. Loupe clearly isn't.

target_title: transparent SVG images with black lines in dark theme

note.body:
This issue is also present with https://static.frame.work/rua3kptws9qoo1kj6hwavr6hy8c6, in Loupe 47.1.

As this issue is open for a year already with yet a fix to be found I can't help but wonder who on earth greenlighted this feature, as is clearly still is in a highly experimental state that should only be accessible through dconf until an algorithm has been found that can guarantee sufficient contrast in all cases. Furthermore, this should be scraped from any version of Loupe still in support asap, and to make Loupe usable with transparent images, it should at least default to a light mode, or better yet have a manual toggle, as with this issue still present, dark mode in this program is very much unusable.

Loupe 47.1 not respecting switching to light mode

note.body: Well of course, a completely broken UX is always better than enabling a very simple fix. And yes, it has everything to do with dark mode, as content with transparency is pretty much only made with a white surface behind it, if it's not explicitly made to have a specific color behind it, which can't be specified in the file formats used. So this is literally something that can only happen in dark mode.

target_title: More complete display of image information

note.body: So the simple desire to actually see all information on one place and not have to fiddle with a dozen programs **and** not having a downgrade in user experience since Gnome defaulting to loupe instead of eog is not enough for you? That's just rich. Maybe you want to check your priorities. Because last time I checked, Gnome was about usability and user-friendly solutions, not about decreasing the UX out of sheer randomness.

You are still not mentioning a use case. From the issue template

> Please focus on the benefit that the feature should bring. Not on how it should be implemented or designed. Preferably, you describe what you actually wanted to do and why, when you noticed that Image Viewer is lacking the feature.

target_title: Loupe 47.1 not respecting switching to light mode

note.body:
> Especially since Loupe does not handle transparency in a way that it could be useable in dark mode.

I don't think what you are looking for has to do with dark mode. Loupe tries to detect a good background color for transparent images. That also happens in light mode. If you have an example for an image for which this fails, you can add it to #139.

target_title: Loupe 47.1 not respecting switching to light mode

note.body: That's just not how anything should work, this doesn't make sense at all. If I switch to something that is not the dark mode I very much expect **every** app to change theme accordingly. This is certainly not a user-friendly design. Especially since Loupe does not handle transparency in a way that it could be useable in dark mode. Please reopen this issue to find a solution that's actually usable and does what the user expects.

target_title: application: Call style_manager from startup
Loupe crashes on start with GTK 4.17: gdk_display_manager_get() was called before gtk_init()
Loupe 47.1 not respecting switching to light mode

note.body:
> neither switched to a light theme when I go into Gnome settings and switch there from dark mode to default

This is contradictory. You are talking about light mode in the issue title and here you are talking about default mode. I assume you are talking about the default mode. Like you can see in settings, not all apps are presented with light windows in the default mode

![image](/uploads/a722118f3175c753c126821f22552e36/image.png)

As you can read in the [HIG](https://developer.gnome.org/hig/guidelines/ui-styling.html#light-and-dark-ui-styles), "apps which display rich visual content like images or video" prefer dark mode. This has been the case for ages in GNOME.

If you want to activate light mode, you have to use

```
$ gsettings set org.gnome.desktop.interface color-scheme prefer-light
```

and can't do it via Settings. There is an MR GNOME/gnome-control-center!2738 for adding this to Settings.

target_title: Loupe 47.1 not respecting switching to light mode

And I don't think the argument with a dedicated program is very convincing, not with the Metadata that's already shown by loupe. If loupe only showed the most basic and format-independent available metadata it may be an argument, but loupe already shows more advanced stuff.

target_title: Print preview for SVGs not working
Loupe Print Dialog Fails on Fedora 41

note.body:
Thanks for reporting the issue.

This is probably a portal and not a Loupe issue. But it would be good to gather some logs.

Can you exit Loupe and start Loupe from the terminal with

```
G_MESSAGES_DEBUG=all loupe
```

And open a second terminal with

```
journalctl -f
```

and then try to open the print dialog?

Can you share the logs from both terminal?

That would be a great help!

Yes, Loupe will never support them for that reason.

target_title: Simple Image Editing Support

note.body: Moreover, [Obfuscate](https://flathub.org/pt-BR/apps/com.belmoussaoui.Obfuscate) is a dedicated app do exactly that.

target_title: Simple Image Editing Support

note.body: I just want to add that blurring and pixelating is not safe. They can both be reversed, and if the option to do that is added people will assume it's safe and will use it without knowing that it can be reversed. So I would recommend against that, and would rather have a box tool to draw a solid color box.

target_title: Simple Image Editing Support

note.body:
I really appreciate you guys adding these tools to the image viewer, because since [this](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/-/merge_requests/1970 "dbus: Restrict callers of private D-Bus APIs") change happened, screenshot tools like ksnip and flamehot got broken and GNOME has lacked a tool for screenshots editing since then. From your mockup, I see you plan to add cropping and highlighting, which is great! I only miss the option of blurring and/or pixelate. That would be useful to redact sensitive information like usernamelike usernames, IP addresses, IP addresses on a screenshot . Would you consider adding that?

![Screenshot_from_2024-10-29_21-28-11](/uploads/bacd7d915b53bcc571e1b077e1ad60b5/Screenshot_from_2024-10-29_21-28-11.png)

Thank you!

target_title: "Save As..." Option is missing

note.body: This is since Loupe 47.

target_title: "Save As..." Option is missing

note.body: You don't have to manually save the image after it's rotated. For JPEG with Exif you can just rotate the image and it will be saved immediately.

target_title: "Save As..." Option is missing

note.body:
It should be obvious, but another use case of "Save as..." is to overwrite the original file. I did this often with eog when I found a rotated image: I just rotated it upright and overwrote it using "Save" or "Save as...".

This is missing badly from loupe, IMHO.

target_title: Assumes Printer Resolution is 300 DPI

note.body:
> Do you need to specificity the DPI?

No, it is just the name of the printer, not an option to specify the DPI. I understand now that it could be easily misunderstood.

>  the image viewer assumes a resolution of 300 DPI
> > How did you figure that out?

I set the printer media size as 2.12" x 0.94". The print dialog interprets my media size as 636px (2.12 * 300) x 282px (0.94 * 300) instead of 430px x 190px, which corresponds to 203 DPI.

> Is there info about the available DPI in the print dialog?

There is no information about DPI in the print dialog, nor any option to select it. There is a tab named 'Advanced' but it does not contain any options related to DPI or other settings.

> Why does 'fills space' fix it? If Loupe produces an image at 300dpi (higher resolution), wouldn't it be printed at a size too large?

The original image has the same dimensions as the 203 DPI printer media: 430px x 190px. The print dialog tries to fill a 636px x 282px space, so selecting 'fill space' ensures it prints correctly at the intended size.

target_title: Assumes Printer Resolution is 300 DPI

note.body:
Hi, thanks for the report.

Sadly, I almost know nothing about the printing stack.

> printing with `lp -d 203dpi image.png` on command line works as expected

Do you need to specificity the DPI? What happens if you don't specify it? If you need to specify it, doesn't that point to something in the printer config/setup/driver being off?

> the image viewer assumes a resolution of 300 DPI

How did you figure that out? Is there info about the available DPI in the print dialog? Does `lp` give you info on what it thinks the DPI is?

> so I have to select the 'fill space' option every time for the image to print at full size

Why does 'fills space' fix it? If Loupe produces an image at 300dpi (higher resolution), wouldn't it be printed at a size too large?

Finally, you could also try out the [nightly](https://welcome.gnome.org/app/Loupe/#installing-a-nightly-build) or flatpak version, since that uses a newer printer API. But I don't expect that to change anything.

target_title: Assumes Printer Resolution is 300 DPI

target_title: Gnome Image Viewer hangs and doesn't display on some images
Thumbnails not updated
Thumbnails not updated

note.body: AFAIK thumbnails in Nautilus should always update automatically. For me at least they always get updated when the file is changed. While opening EOG is certainly an interesting workaround, it's not the task of the image viewer to update the thumbnails in Nautilus. That EOG does is more or less by accident since it uses the thumbnails itself.

target_title: Add option to remove sideways fadein when using next/prev buttons
Image Editing: Crop

note.body: I feel like you haven't read the existing comments in this issue.

target_title: Image Editing: Crop

note.body:
Great progress Sophie! I have been testing the latest flatpak artefact from MR and have a few comments:

* Currently, dragging moves the selection rectangle. If you have already pressed 'Apply', it is not possible to get back parts of the image that are outside the selection without resetting everything. My suggestion is to move the image within the selection rectangle instead, and perhaps even allow zooming in and out. This would make it possible to increase the size of the selection without having to reset everything. It would also be similar to panning and zooming when viewing an image.
* It is not possible to resize the selection rectangle using the handles once it has been applied. Some image editors allow you to increase the selection indefinitely by zooming out at a constant rate once a certain threshold has been reached by dragging the mouse away from the selection handles. Personally, I have never found this to work well. But perhaps it would be a good idea to leave some padding around the cropped area to allow the selection to be increased again a little (step by step if necessary).
* The explicit "Apply" button feels a bit strange to me. I'm so used to the selection being applied after a short delay on iOS. There it is applied 1 second or so after the last time the selection was adjusted or the image moved or zoomed. Combined with my suggestion above to move and zoom the image within the selection rectangle, I think we could get rid of this button.
